exercise_1.tfprompt: Do flowers WILT if it doesn't rain for a long time?
If you go to watch a football game, are you a SPECTATOR?
Are rocks DURABLE?
Would a curving road be a DIRECT route between two places?
Can catsup TRICKLE?
Would Los Angeles be CONSIDERED a large city?
Does a diver PLUNGE into the water?
Are DELEGATES sometimes elected?
Do you have to be CERTAIN of the answer before you ask a question?
Would a severe burn cause AGONY?
Does a soldier standing at attention SLUMP?
Is it COURTEOUS to slam a door in someone's face?
Can you VARY the clothes you wear?
Is "No, you absolutely can't go" a DEFINITE answer?
Is ice SCARCE at the North Pole?

Her feelings about school VARY; sometimes she likes it, and sometimes she    doesn't.
He wanted some DEFINITE news, not just hints and rumors.
That summer there was such a SCARCITY of water that no one was allowed to take a bath.

definitions.deftext: to droop, sag        To WILT is to droop, to lose freshness or spirit. The word  is often used about plants or flowers.       "The lack of water caused many plants to WILT."     The word can also be used in a more general sense.   "Our enthusiasm for the trip started to WILT when we    found out how much it was going to cost."     "The witness's confidence WILTED under the harsh       questioning of the lawyer."          "Our team started well, but WILTED late in the     game."

an onlooker, viewer,        watcher             The form spect is seen in many words and always means   to see or to look at. Some examples are: spectacles (eye-   glasses); inspect (to examine carefully); and spectacular       (wonderful to look at). A SPECTATOR is someone who is    looking on at what is happening; he does not take part in  the event, but simply watches it.        "The SPECTATORS were amused by the clown."       "We were unwilling SPECTATORS of the robbery."       "The SPECTATORS at the tennis match cheered the      winner."

lasting, enduring,         permanent, strong            See -able under Suffixes. The dur part of the word comes   from a Latin word meaning to last. It is also found in the English word endure. Something that is DURABLE is      able to last. It won't break or fall apart easily.    "These toys are DURABLE. Your child will use them     for years."            "He was a DURABLE athlete. He never missed a game    because of injury."           "The can opener wasn't very DURABLE. If you      dropped it on the floor it would need to be repaired."   Other forms of the word: DURABILITY, n.

straight, straightforward         DIRECT means straight, "going from one point to an-     other by the shortest path."         "We wanted to take the DIRECT route to the beach,    but he wanted to drive all over the place and see the  sights."             "Go DIRECTLY home. Don't stop anywhere."        DIRECT is also used about other things besides routes     and distances, but it has the same general meaning.     "The accident was a DIRECT result of your careless-     ness."             "Don't beat around the bush. I want a DIRECT an-    swer."             Other forms ofthe word: DIRECTION, n.

to drip, flow slowly       TRICKLE means to drip or fiow slowly. It is used about   water, blood, oil, or other liquids.        "Blood was TRICKLING out of his mouth."       "The water TRICKLED out of the faucet."       TRICKLE can also be used about other things that can    be said to flow.          "The sugar TRICKLED through her fingers."        "The students TRICKLED out of the classroom."       TRICKLE is also a noun.         "She wiped the TRICKLE of blood from his lips."     Melt is often chosen as the meaning of TRICKLE on the   Pretest.Something like an ice cube may TRICKLE as it     melts, but things that are not melting may TRICKLE as    well.

to think about        To CONSIDER means to think about in some way.     "You must CONSIDER how your father will feel if you    do that."            "I've never CONSIDERED him stupid, just a little      slow-moving."             CONSIDERATION is the act of CONSIDERING.        "You should take into CONSIDERATION the fact       that she's only two years old."        In a different sense, CONSIDERATION means thought-       fulness.             "He showed great CONSIDERATION for his parents       by always letting them know when he expected to be    back."             Other forms of the word: CONSIDERATION, n.       CONSIDERATE, adj.

to dive, submerge, dip       To PLUNGE is to dive down into something such as    water or a hole.          "The kite PLUNGED into the lake."        "Alice lost her balance and PLUNGED into the well."     To PLUNGE something is to thrust it, throw it, or cause   it to fall into something.         "He PLUNGED the shovel into the ground."       "She turned out the lights and PLUNGED the room     into darkness."            "The stock market crash PLUNGED the nation into a     depression."             The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is step. To     step into something is also to go into it, but PLUNGE   suggests a much more complete and sudden movement.

a representative, deputy        A DELEGATE is a person who has the power to act for  someone else. The word is often used about people elected    to represent a group at a convention or conference.     "The DELEGATES met to vote on the party's posi-     tion on these matters."          "Each class in the school elected a DELEGATE to     represent it in the student government."        DELEGATE is also a verb meaning "to appoint as a rep-   resentative."             "We DELEGATED Jim to be the spokesperson for the     club."             DELEGATE can also mean to entrust or assign.      "He DELEGATED complete authority to us to act as     we saw fit in this matter."        Other forms of the word: DELEGATION, n.

sure          If something isCERTAIN, it is sure; there is no doubt    about it. Both people and things can beCERTAIN.      "Gloria isCERTAIN that it will be sunny on the day    of the picnic."           "ACERTAIN cure for hiccups is to hold your breath."     "There is noCERTAIN way to prevent war from      breaking out."            The noun form ofCERTAIN isCERTAINTY. ACER-        TAINTY is something that is sure; there is no doubt    about it.            "He was assured of winning; it was aCERTAINTY      that he would come in first."        Many people confuseCERTAIN with right. You can be      CERTAIN of something, though, and be wrong.       Other forms of the word:CERTAINTY, n.

great pain, torment        AGONY is great pain or suffering, either of the mind or of  the body.            "Her headaches caused her constant AGONY."        "He felt extreme AGONY when he saw the results of    his careless driving."           "She looked on in AGONY as the soldiers took away    all her possessions."           To AGONIZE is to suffer AGONY.        "Susan AGONIZED over her hopeless situation, but       couldn't do anything about it."         Other forms of the word: AGONIZE, v.       AGONIZED, adj.            AGONIZING, adj.

to sag, droop, slouch       SLUMP means "to drop down heavily," to sag or slouch.    "His shoulders SLUMPED under the weight of the      pack he carried."           Someone who SLUMPS is often tired.        "He staggered into the room and SLUMPED down      into a chair."           SLUMP is sometimes used of other things besides people.     "The ice cream business always SLUMPS during the      cold weather."            SLUMP is also a noun.         "There has been a SLUMP in the price of corn."

polite, well-mannered         To be COURTEOUS is to be polite, to have good man-   ners.             "The COURTEOUS boy held the door open for his     mother."             "Even though he was very angry at the rude question,    he managed to give a COURTEOUS answer."       "With a COURTEOUS smile, she stepped aside to let     the woman with all the packages get on the bus first."   The noun form of COURTEOUS is COURTESY, which      means politeness or polite behavior.         "She showed great COURTESY to the unexpected       visitor, although she was tired and wanted to go to    bed."             Other forms of the word: COURTESY, n.

to change, become different       When something VARIES it becomes different.        "The colors of the sky at sunset VARY from minute to   minute."             To VARY something is to make it different, to change it.   "She never VARIES her hairstyle; she has always worn     it short and curly."          "He tried to VARY the way he taught the class so that  his students wouldn't get bored."         An adjective form of VARY is VARIABLE, which means     changeable.             "The forecast for today says that there will be VARI-    ABLE winds and sunny skies."         Other forms of the word: VARIABLE, adj.       VARIOUS, adj.

exact, clear, precise        Whatever is clear, exact, and leaves no room for doubt is   DEFINITE.             "We have made DEFINITE plans to leave on Satur-     day morning."            "Can you be more DEFINITE about the place where     I'm supposed to meet you? So far you've been rather    vague."             "He made a DEFINITE promise to help us."      The adverb form, DEFINITELY, is often used to mean     surely, positively, precisely.           "He DEFINITELY has a hearing problem. Three sep-      arate ear examinations have confirmed it."        "I will DEFINITELY be there by ten o'clock."

rare, not enough, uncommon       When something is SCARCE, it is rare or in very short   supply. There is hardly any of it.       "Before these animals were protected by law, they      were becoming very SCARCE."          "When food gets SCARCE, the price goes up."      "During the strike, steel became very SCARCE in      some parts of the country."         The noun from SCARCE is SCARCITY, which means a     short supply of something.          "There were long lines at gasoline stations because of     the SCARCITY of fuel."          Other forms of the word: SCARCITY, n.

exercise_1.tfprompt: Do people ordinarily show their AFFECTION by kicking each other?
Is the wheel a MODERN invention?
If something is unique, does it have any DUPLICATES?
Can a person HESITATE while he is writing?
Can you FLING a refrigerator very far?
Is a clown COMICAL?
If the sky is OVERCAST, is it sunny?
Do people PERSPIRE more when it's cold than when it is hot?
Would a sad story cause people to CHUCKLE?
Is a NUDGE softer than a punch?
Is a concrete sidewalk GLOSSY?
Can a DISTRICT be very large?
Is a five dollar bill IDENTICAL to a ten dollar bill?
Can a tree CALCULATE?
Can you ATTEND a play that you've never seen before?

exercise_2.tfprompt: She comes from a very AFFECTIONATE family; the children never leave the     house without first kissing their mother.
It was a very MODERN idea; no one would have thought such a thing a few years ago.
She DUPLICATED to us about her report card; she had really failed two    courses.
Sally HESITATED for several minutes before she agreed.
How far can you FLING that stone?
The teacher became very COMICAL and yelled at us for being late.
I feel as gloomy as the weather when the sky is OVERCAST.
The PERSPIRATION soaked through his shirt as he struggled to lift the boxes.
He CHUCKLED as he remembered the jokes the comedian had told.
He pushed it with all his might but it didn't NUDGE.
This new shampoo is supposed to make your hair GLOSSY.
She lived in a rundown shack in the poor DISTRICT of town.
She wore the IDENTICAL wedding gown that her mother had worn thirty years    ago.
Jim CALCULATED the distance from the Earth to the moon.
Because of the rain, the ATTENDANCE at the game was poor.

definitions.deftext: love, fondness         AFFECTION is a warm feeling of fondness and tender-     ness. It is almost the same as love, although usually not   quite as strong.           "He has a very real AFFECTION for his father."     "He felt little AFFECTION toward the town where he     had grown up."           The adjective form of AFFECTION is AFFECTION-       ATE, which means loving or fond.        "The teacher's AFFECTIONATE attitude toward the        young children makes them like her in return."      "He gave the dog an AFFECTIONATE pat."       Other forms of the word: AFFECTIONATE, adj.

present-day, up-to-date         MODERN means "having to do with present or recent     times."             "It is a MODERN building, built just a few years ago."   "Are people happier in MODERN times than they      were in the past?"          "She believes that anything that is MODERN is better     than something that is old."

a copy, double        DUPLICATE is related to the word double. Both come     from a Latin word meaning two. A DUPLICATE is an ex-   act copy of something.          "This machine can make several DUPLICATES of       that letter in just a few seconds."       "The twins are exact DUPLICATES of each other;      even their voices sound the same."        DUPLICATE may also be used as an adjective.      "We have DUPLICATE keys to the car. We keep one    set in the desk."          As a verb, the word is pronounced dU'-pli-kAt, and means    "to make a copy of."         "She tried to DUPLICATE the teacher's movements."       "He DUPLICATED the directions for getting to his      house and sent everyone a copy."        Other forms of the word: DUPLICATION, n.

to pause, delay for a      moment             To HESITATE is to show signs of uncertainty by pausing    or delaying for a short time.        "We could tell he had not studied enough from the    way he HESITATED before he spelled each word."      "The cat HESITATED before stepping on the new-      fallen snow."            "If you need anything, do not HESITATE to ask for    it."             HESITATION is the noun from HESITATE. It is the act    of pausing or holding back.         "Midway through the actor's speech there were several      long HESITATIONS, and it became obvious that he      had forgotten his lines."          Other forms of the word: HESITANT, adj.       HESITATION, n.

to throw, hurl, cast       FLING means just about the same as throw, but often    adds a sense of force or violence to throw.     "Angrily he FLUNG the books across the room."      "Tom FLUNG the stone with all his might."      "The wrestler FLINGS his opponent to the ground."      To "FLING your arms up in the air" is to raise them sud- dently and unexpectedly.           Usage: The past tense of FLING is FLUNG.

funny, humorous, amusing        COMICAL means funny or amusing.         "The puppy was so COMICAL that we burst out     laughing."             "She entered the room with a COMICAL expression      on her face, and we knew that something funny had    happened."             "He tries to amuse us with COMICAL stories, but we    don't think they're funny at all."        The noun form of COMICAL is COMIC. A COMIC is a   person who amuses others by telling funny stories and     jokes.             Other forms of the word: COMIC, n.

cloudy, gloomy         OVERCAST is used about clouds and the weather and     means clouded over, cloudy.          "The sky was OVERCAST, and it looked as if it were   going to rain."           "November was filled with cold, OVERCAST days."       OVERCAST is also a noun.         "The few breaks in the OVERCAST convinced us that     the weather was going to clear up."       The most popular incorrect answer on the Pretest is     rainy. OVERCAST justmeans cloudy, however; when the       sky is OVERCAST it might or might not rain.

sweat          PERSPIRATION is a polite word for sweat.       "He was covered with PERSPIRATION after the 100-      yard dash."            "The horse's PERSPIRATION looks like white foam."       "The room was so warm that everyone's face was shin-    ing with PERSPIRATION."           The verb form is PERSPIRE.         "We PERSPIRED in the hot sunlight."        Effort is often chosen as the meaning of PERSPIRA-     TION. Effort might cause to sweat, but effort and PER-    SPIRATION are not the same thing.        Other forms of the word: PERSPIRE, v.

to laugh quietly        To CHUCKLE is to laugh, usually quietly or to yourself.    "He CHUCKLED while he read the funny story, and     sometimes he laughed out loud."         "You're not supposed to CHUCKLE when Ken is talk-     ing to you even if you think he's funny."     CHUCKLE is also used as a noun and means a laugh.   "We got a few CHUCKLES out of the show, but in   general it wasn't very funny."

to touch or push gently      To NUDGE someone is to touch or push him slightly, in   order to call attention to something or to get him to do  something.             "She NUDGED him and pointed to her watch, letting     him know it was time to go."       "We NUDGED Henry forward until he was at the     front of the stage."          NUDGE is also a noun.         "I gave him a NUDGE and told him to come with me."

smooth and shiny, highly       polished             The GLOSS of something is its smooth, shining surface.     "Feel the GLOSS of this silk shirt."       Something which is GLOSSY has a smooth, shining sur-     face. See -y under Suffixes.         "He polished his car until the entire surface was     GLOSSY."             "You could see your face reflected in his GLOSSY     leather shoes."            Other forms of the word: GLOSS, n.

an area, region        A DISTRICT is an area that has a special purpose or a  special character that makes it different from other areas.     It can be either large or small.       "In New York, the financial DISTRICT is centered      around Wall Street."           "The DISTRICT where we live is marked off by rivers    at either end."           "There isn't any high school in our DISTRICT, so we    have to go into the city."        "Several DISTRICTS of the town were without elec-      tricity because of the storm last night."       The DISTRICT of Columbia is a special area that con-    tains the capital of the United States.

same          Two things that are IDENTICAL are the same; they are    exactly alike and agree in every detail. IDENTICAL      twins are twins who look exactly alike.       "This print is IDENTICAL to the one we saw in the   art gallery two weeks ago."         "No two people have IDENTICAL fingerprints.        Everyone's fingerprints are different."

to compute, count,        figure             Calculus was a Latin word for pebble. People used to use   pebbles to help in adding or subtracting numbers. So to    CALCULATE is to work with numbers, to compute.      "If we know how many miles we have to go, we can  CALCULATE how long it will take."        "Jim's father CALCULATED the cost of sending him      to college."            People now often have CALCULATORS to do their CAL-     CULATING for them.           "We are allowed to use our pocket CALCULATORS      during the math test."          Another meaning of CALCULATE is to think or suppose.     "I CALCULATE that Smith will win the election."      Other forms of the word: CALCULATION, n.       CALCULATING, adj.            CALCULATOR, n.

presence          To ATTEND something is to be present at it.     "They ATTENDED church every Sunday."         ATTENDANCE is the noun from ATTEND. ATTEN-       DANCE means the presence of one or more people at    some place.            "We were surprised by the ATTENDANCE of Bill      Johnson at Sam's funeral. They had been enemies for     years."             "Seven pupils got certificates for perfect ATTEN-       DANCE this year."           ATTENDANCE also means "the number of persons who      are present at something."          "School ATTENDANCE has gone down because fewer       children are being born."          "There was a large ATTENDANCE at the concert."      Other forms of the word: ATTEND, v.

exercise_1.tfprompt: Does a TRAGEDY have a happy ending?
Are some PORTIONS larger than others?
Can you INTERRUPT a meeting?
Is a MOUND always huge?
Would a person who is under a lot of STRESS usually be carefree and happy?
Do invited guests INTRUDE?
Do businesses like people to NEGLECT to pay their bills?
Would most people OBJECT to receiving a present?
Would you RECOMMEND buying a radio that doesn't work?
Is it POSSIBLE to see something that is invisible?
Do most people like to get the right SOLUTION to a problem?
Do Americans OBSERVE the Fourth of July as a holiday?
Can a movie theater LURE customers by showing terrible movies?
Does it take money to PURCHASE most things?
Would a person caught outside in a snowstorm feel SNUG?

exercise_2.tfprompt: She is so tender-hearted that even the death of an ant strikes her as TRAGIC.
Please read the PORTION of the story starting on page 35 and ending on page
After the program was over it was INTERRUPTED.
The child made a MOUND of rocks at the beach.
The doctor STRESSED the importance of keeping fit.
She put the "Do Not Disturb" sign on her door to prevent any INTRUSIONS.
He NEGLECTED some of the small details and concentrated on the important    problems.
Their OBJECTION was to make it to the top of the mountain before dark.
They RECOMMENDED that we leave early if we wanted to get to the show on time.
We thought that there was no POSSIBILITY that we could lose the game.
Her SOLUTION for any problem was to forget about it.
He OBSERVED that the days got longer in the springtime.
We put some food at the bottom of the tree to LURE the kitten down.
Because he needed money, Tom was forced to PURCHASE his car.
She was quite SNUG in her comfortable chair by the fireplace.

definitions.deftext: a disaster, calamity, misfor-       tune             A TRAGEDY is a very sad event that usually ends in   some kind of misfortune or disaster. Originally, a TRAG-     EDY was a play that ended very unhappily, the opposite    of comedy. Now, in addition to being a play or book with  a sad ending, a TRAGEDY is any kind of disaster that   can happen to a person.         "We were all saddened by the TRAGEDY of the presi-    dent's death."            "He acted as if it were a TRAGEDY that he couldn't   have the car that evening."         The adjective from TRAGEDY is TRAGIC, which means      very sad, unfortunate.           "The once famous star died in TRAGIC circum-      stances."             "He has such a low, sad voice that everything he says   sounds TRAGIC."            Other forms of the word: TRAGIC, adj.

a share, part        A PORTION is a part or share in something.     "I think that his PORTION of the money is larger    than mine."            "Each child received a PORTION of the marbles."      The word is often used about food, meaning "the share of   the food given to one person."        "The restaurant gave them such large PORTIONS       that no one could finish."

a pile, heap, small hill      A MOUND is a small pile. The word is often used about  piled-up earth.            "The small MOUND in the backyard made them think     something might be buried there."         MOUND can also be used about anything that is piled up.   "There was a MOUND of dishes in the sink."     "He had a MOUND of dirty clothes in his room."

to break in on, break off     To INTERRUPT someone is to break in on him while he   is doing or saying something, so that he has to stop.   "She kept INTERRUPTING the teacher to ask silly      questions."             "I locked the door of my room so that I wouldn't be  INTERRUPTED while I was studying."         You can also INTERRUPT things like programs.       "They INTERRUPTED the program to give a special      news bulletin."            Other forms of the word: INTERRUPTION, n.

pressure, emphasis         STRESS is a noun and a verb. It has several different   uses, all having to do with pressure or importance put on   something. STRESS can mean importance or emphasis.       "They place too much STRESS on having a winning     football team at that school."         It is the force with which a particular word is spoken.   "He always STRESSED the first word in the sen-     tence."             STRESS is also mental or emotional pressure.       "With all her problems, she has been under a lot of   STRESS lately."            Danger is often chosen as a meaning of STRESS on the   Pretest. Danger might cause STRESS in the sense of     mental pressure, but the words have different meanings.

to enter or come uninvited,      trespass             To INTRUDE is to force yourself into a place where you   are not welcome.           "I hope I'm not INTRUDING on you, but I'd like to   talk with you for a few minutes."       "People are always INTRUDING on my privacy."       Other things besides people can INTRUDE.        "The noises INTRUDED on my thoughts."        An INTRUSION is an act of INTRUDING.       "I was annoyed at these constant INTRUSIONS."       Other forms of the word: INTRUDER, n.       INTRUSION, n.            INTRUSIVE, adj.            Usage: INTRUDE is usually followed by on or upon.

to fail to do, overlook, forget     To NEGLECT to do something is to fail to do it, either  purposely or not.           "Bill NEGLECTED to follow the instructions, and as      a result he did it all wrong."       "Mary's mother got mad at her when she NE-     GLECTED to make her bed."         In a slightly different use, to NEGLECT something is to    fail to pay proper attention to it, to ignore it.    "They NEGLECTED their homework in order to       watch television."            "Sally's parents were so busy with other matters that     they often NEGLECTED her."          Other forms of the word: NEGLECTFUL, adj.

a protest         To OBJECT to something is to speak in opposition to it.   "I OBJECT to the way you keep calling me a child. I'm  practically an adult."           An OBJECTION is something said in opposition, dis-      agreement, or refusal.           "When we asked if we could go, he said he had no OB- JECTION."             "Their OBJECTION to our plan was that it would cost    too much money."           "I raised a strong OBJECTION to the idea of starting    the game later."           Other forms of the word: OBJECT, v.

to speak favorably        of, advise, suggest           To RECOMMEND is to speak favorably of, to say that    someone or something is suited for a job or a purpose.   "I RECOMMEND him to you highly. He's perfect for     thejob."             "We RECOMMEND this paint for your house. It will     last for years."           When you RECOMMEND that someone do something,       you suggest it as a good thing to do.     "The teacherRECOMMENDS that Susan watch less        television and study more."          "The doctor RECOMMENDS that you stay in bed to-     day."             Other forms of the word: RECOMMENDATION, n.

chance, likelihood         Something that is POSSIBLE can be done or can happen.    "It is POSSIBLE that we will all pass the test."    POSSIBILITY is the state of being POSSIBLE. If there     is a POSSIBILITY of something happening, we are not     sure that it will happen, but it may happen.     "There is a POSSIBILITY that it will rain tomorrow."     "Is there any POSSIBILITY that you will be here     early?"             Other forms of the word: POSSIBLE, adj.

an answer, explanation        SOLUTION is the noun from the verb to solve. A SOLU-   TION is the answer to a problem or the explanation of a  difficulty or a mystery.          "Everyone has suggestions about how to find the SO-     LUTION to the unemployment problem."         "Tom spent hours puzzling over the question without      success, but Richard saw the SOLUTION imme-       diately."             "A fight is not the best SOLUTION for a disagree-    ment."

to note, notice, watch careful-      ly; to pay attention to; to remark, comment      OBSERVE has several common meanings. To OBSERVE       something is to watch it carefully, to take notice of it.   "He OBSERVED them walking down the street just      before dawn."            "She OBSERVED that the animals in the zoo didn't     like the new lights."          To OBSERVE a rule is to follow it. To OBSERVE a holi-  day is to celebrate it. To OBSERVE also means "to say   by way of a comment."         " 'I think they're getting tired,' Mary OBSERVED, as     she watched the children play."         Other forms of the word: OBSERVANCE, n.       OBSERVATION, n.            OBSERVATORY, n.

to tempt, attract, entice       Originally, a LURE was a bunch of feathers roughly re-    sembling a bird which was used to attract and recall a   trained hawk from its flight. From this the word came to   be used about anything that attracts or tempts someone.     "The LURE of the sea has drawn many men away    from their homes."           To LURE therefore means to attract or tempt.      "The football game on TV LURED them away from     their homework."            "The hope of becoming rich LURED many people to     California during the Gold Rush."

to buy         To PURCHASE something is to buy it.       "We always PURCHASE our groceries at the super-      market."             "He went to the city to PURCHASE a ring."     "Money can't PURCHASE love."          PURCHASE is also a noun, meaning "something that is     bought."             "She put all her PURCHASES into one bag."      Most people who get this item wrong think PURCHASE     means sell, which is the exact opposite of the correct    meaning.

comfortable, cozy, warm        SNUG was originally used about ships that are neat and    well-prepared for bad weather. To be SNUG now means     to be comfortable, especially to be warm and dry and pro-   tected from the weather.          "She felt very SNUG in her warm bed as she listened   to the wind howl outside."         SNUG is also used about places and things that make us   feel comfortable.            "As he shoveled snow he wished he were back in his   SNUG little room sitting by the fireplace."       In a different sense, SNUG means closely fitting, tight.     "This coat is a bit SNUG. Perhaps I should try on a  larger size."

exercise_1.tfprompt: Should a pilot be able to NAVIGATE a plane?
Is it easy to see a FAINT star?
Is running over a dog HOMICIDE?
Could a person SHRIEK from fear?
Are reading, writing, and arithmetic ELEMENTARY subjects?
Is it easy to INCINERATE gold and silver?
Are most people angry OCCASIONALLY?
Can you only ASSAULT someone by hitting him?
Do people MUFFLE up in order to keep warm?
Would a good racehorse HOBBLE?
Are a father and his son LINKED in any way?
Does wood RESIST fire?
Does an airplane crash usually cause GRIEF?
Can a MOOD change quickly?
Could an explosion cause buildings to QUAKE?

exercise_2.tfprompt: The captain let his son NAVIGATE the ship through the canal.
Her cries were too FAINT to be heard in the next room.
He was accused of HOMICIDE in the death of his wife.
The baby's constant SHRIEKS kept us from getting a good night's sleep.
There are some ELEMENTARY things you have to know before you can drive a  car.
They INCINERATED that we had made a mistake.
Alice was OCCASIONALLY late for school; she was almost never on time.
The cruel strangers ASSAULTED him with clubs and rocks.
The fielder MUFFLED the easy ground ball.
He HOBBLED to the other side of the room to pick up his crutches.
They LINKED the boat from the dock by cutting the rope.
There was considerable RESISTANCE in Congress to the president's plan.
Only the passage of time could ease the GRIEF she felt over his death.
Beth is very MOODY today. She may yell at you for no reason.
The explosions made the nearby buildings QUAKE.

definitions.deftext: to steer, sail         NAVIGATE is related to the word navy. Both come from     a Latin word meaning ship. The basic meaning of NAVI-     GATE is to "steer a ship." Now the word also means to   steer or direct your course anywhere, in the water, on the    ground, or in the air.          "The pilot NAVIGATED the damaged plane to a       successful landing.             ,              .              "Can you NAVIGATE the boat through the rapids?"       "We expect you to be able to NAVIGATE anywhere      after you have finished this course in sailing."       Other forms of the word: NAVIGATION, n.        NAVIGATOR, n.

dim, weak, unclear, indistinct        Something that is FAINT lacks strength. A person who      "feels FAINT" feels sick and dizzy, as if he or she were   about to pass out. FAINT can be used about sounds,     lights, smells, memories, and other things.         "There was a FAINT smell of roses in the air as they   approached the garden."            "He could barely hear the FAINT sound of the distant     train whistle."             "There is only a very FAINT hope that any of the    trapped miners will survive."           The verb to FAINT is usually used about people and     means "to lose consciousness," to pass out.        "Many people FAINTED in the heat during the long      speech."

the killing of a human       being, murder             HOMICIDE is the killing of a person by another person.     "The medical examiner ruled that the death was a      HOMICIDE."              "The detective was assigned to investigate cases of       HOMICIDE."              HOMICIDE and murder have almost the same meaning,       but there is a slight difference. Murder is the unlawful     killing of a person. If you kill someone in self-defense,     that would be HOMICIDE, but it wouldn't be murder,      since the killing would be legal. All murders are HOMI-     CIDES, but not all HOMICIDES are murders.

to scream, screech, cry out       To SHRIEK is to scream or screech suddenly or loudly,     usually with a very high sound.         "She SHRIEKED when she heard the unexpected        knock on the door."           SHRIEK is also a noun meaning a scream.       "She let out a piercing SHRIEK when she saw the     accident."              "The SHRIEKS of the angry birds disturbed my nap."

basic,           fundamental, simple             An ELEMENT is a basic part of something. The chemical     ELEMENTS, for example, are the basic substances like       oxygen and carbon which combine to form all matter.      Something that is ELEMENTARY, therefore, has to do       with the basic or first parts of a subject or a thing.   "He learned some of the ELEMENTARY steps, but       he never became an expert dancer."         "You have to pass ELEMENTARY French before you       can take advanced courses."           An ELEMENTARY school teaches children basic sub-        jects like reading, writing, and arithmetic.         Other forms of the word: ELEMENT, n.

to burn, reduce to        ashes              INCINERATE comes from the Latin word for ashes and      means to "burn to ashes."          "He INCINERATED the pile of leaves in the back-      yard."              An INCINERATOR is a place for INCINERATING, a       furnace.              "We placed all the trash in the INCINERATOR."       Other forms of the word: INCINERATOR, n.

sometimes,           now and then, at times          OCCASIONALLY is an adverb from OCCASIONAL,         which means "happening now and then."         "There were OCCASIONAL mistakes in the book, but       in general it was quite good."         OCCASIONALLY means at times, now and then. On the      Pretest, many people pick often as the meaning of OCCA-     SIONALLY, but something that happens OCCASION-         ALLY doesn't happen very often at all.        "She OCCASIONALLY went to the movies, but pre-       , ferred watching television."           "We have turkey only OCCASIONALLY-maybe two         or three times a year."          Other forms of the word: OCCASION, n.        OCCASIONAL, adj.

to attack          To ASSAULT someone is to attack him, usually violently      or suddenly.             "The three youths ASSAULTED the defenseless girl."        "The soldiers ASSAULTED the enemy positions."         ASSAULT is also a noun.          "We managed to turn back the enemy's ASSAULT."       Sometimes an ASSAULT can be in words.        "The mayor considered the newspaper articles to be an      ASSAULT on his good reputation."

to wrap up, cover over; to      deaden the sound of           To MUFFLE or MUFFLE up something is to wrap it up.    You can MUFFLE something to keep it warm or hide it.    "She MUFFLED her neck with a scarf."        "He MUFFLED up in a heavy coat before going out     into the cold."            Or you can MUFFLE something to keep it from being     noisy.              "They tried to MUFFLE the noise of the machine by     wrapping it in cotton."           On a car, a MUFFLER is a device that deadens the sound   ofthe engine.             Many people choose move as the meaning of MUFFLE,      perhaps because MUFFLE sounds like shuffl,e, which is a      kind of movement.            Other forms of the word: MUFFLER, n.        Usage: MUFFLE is sometimes followed by up.

to limp, move awkwardly; to       hamper the action of           To HOBBLE is to walk with difficulty, as if your feet or   legs were hurt.            "The old man HOBBLED down the street, leaning       heavily on his cane."           "With his broken ankle Don can barely HOBBLE."       To HOBBLE someone or something is to cause it to move    awkwardly, to hamper or bother it.         "The tight-fitting shoes HOBBLED her as she tried to      walk across the room."

to join, connect         A LINK is one of the rings or loops in a chain. To LINK things is to connect them, to join them together the way    LINKS are joined in a chain.         "They built a bridge to LINK the two sides of the    river."              "Our common interest in fishing LINKS us together."       LINK is often used with up.         "The two ends were LINKED up with one another by     means of a rope."

to oppose, withstand         To RESIST something is to withstand its power or force.     "The enemy RESISTED our attack."          "The youth was charged with RESISTING arrest."        "I couldn't RESIST buying this necklace."         "This glass can RESIST temperatures of up to a thou-     sand degrees."             RESISTANCE is the power of RESISTING.         "The insects had developed a RESISTANCE to that       poison"-that is, they could withstand its effects.        Other forms of the word: RESISTANCE, n.        RESISTANT, adj.

deep sorrow, sadness, mental suffering,       misery              GRIEF is a very strong degree of sadness or sorrow.     GRIEF usually suggests sadness that is caused by loss,      pain, regret, or despair, and that lasts for a long time or is  very deep.             "No one could ease her GRIEF when she discovered      that her son had died."          "Jim's GRIEF over her decision to leave him was al-     most unbearable."             The phrase "to come to GRIEF" means "to meet misfor-     tune or disappointment."            "This project will come to GRIEF unless we work      harder."              The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is anger.       Anger is another strong emotion, but it is not the same as   GRIEF.              Other forms of the word: GRIEVE, v.

a state of mind, feeling       A MOOD is a state of mind, the way a person feels men-  tally at a certain time.          "His MOODS change constantly. He's happy one min-       ute and sad the next."          "She said she isn't in the MOOD to work right now."    MOOD is also used about the general spirits of a group of   people.              "The country is in an angry MOOD."        "His writings reflect the MOOD of the times."       A person who is MOODY has MOODS that often change.     MOODY is usually used about a person who often has un-    happy or angry MOODS.           "He becomes MOODY and won't talk to anyone when-      ever he loses a game."          Other forms of the word: MOODY, adj.

to shake, tremble         QUAKE means to shake, usually violently.         "Every time the train roared by the entire house would     QUAKE."              People QUAKE from cold or fear.         "When I saw the monster I started QUAKING so      badly that I couldn't run."          QUAKE, as a noun, is short for earthquake. In an earth-    quake the ground starts shaking, which causes great       damage to buildings and property.
