definitions.deftext: to set up, make firm,       start up, bring about, found          ESTABLISH is related to the adjective stable, which       means solid, fixed, not easily moved. The basic meaning      of ESTABLISH is "to make something stable." The word      is usually used in the sense "to set up or bring about   something," usually on a firm or stable basis. It is often    used about businesses:            "This company was ESTABLISHED in 1959."         About customs:             "Who ESTABLISHED the custom of kissing under-        neath mistletoe?"             About rights, claims, facts, and the like:        "It took a long time to ESTABLISH the facts of the    case."              And about people:            "They were comfortably ESTABLISHED in their new        headquarters."              In all cases, ESTABLISH has the idea of setting some-     thing up, putting something on a firm foundation.       Other forms of the word: ESTABLISHMENT, n.

a journey, voyage         An EXPEDITION is a journey or voyage which usually is     made for a definite reason. It is usually well organized,     and its purpose is often to explore.        "He went on an EXPEDITION into the jungle to      study the rare plants that grow there."        "When we had everything packed for our vacation, it      looked like we were going on an EXPEDITION to      Alaska."              "The military EXPEDITION lasted two months."

to teach, educate, inform;        to order             To INSTRUCT someone is to give knowledge to him. Of-     ten it means just about the same as teach.      "The teacher INSTRUCTED the class about how to       do multiplication."             "The paino teacher comes to the house to INSTRUCT      Sue."              Sometimes INSTRUCT has a stronger meaning-to or-        der or direct.            "The teacher INSTRUCTED us to return to our seats      immediately."              The adjective from INSTRUCT is INSTRUCTIVE,         which means "giving knowledge," informative.          "The class was very INSTRUCTIVE. I think we all      learned a lot."            Other forms of the word: INSTRUCTION, n.        INSTRUCTIVE, adj.             INSTRUCTOR, n.

twisted, rugged, knotty         GNARLED is used about the rough, twisted, knotty ap-      pearance of the branches on oak and other trees.      "The kite was caught in the GNARLED branches of      the tree."             From this use the word has come to be applied to any-   thing or anyone that looks rugged, tough, or weatherbeat-      en.              "His hands were GNARLED from years of hard       work."              "The GNARLED old cowboy told us many exciting       tales of his younger days."          Other forms of the word: GNARL, v.

to over praise; to show favorably      To FLATTER someone is to praise him more than he de-    serves, usually with the hope of gaining something.       "The noblemen FLATTERED the king by telling him       what a great leader he was."         "Ted tried to FLATTER her, but she realized he      wasn't sincere with his compliments."          In a related sense, FLATTER means "to show off to ad-    vantage."              "That photograph FLATTERS her. She's not really        that good-looking."             Other forms of the word: FLATTERY, n.

to destroy          completely, wipe out, put an end to, get rid of     To EXTERMINATE something is to wipe it out, to de-     stroy it totally. The word is used about people, ideas, in-    sects, diseases, and other things.          "The enemy tried to EXTERMINATE us, but some-       how a few of us managed to survive."       "Our attempt to EXTERMINATE this new disease        was completely successful; no cases of it were re-      ported last year."            An EXTERMINATOR is someone who EXTERMI-         NATES, particularly someone whose job is to EXTER-       MINATEinsects, rats, or other pests.          "The new house was so filled with bugs, we had to call   the EXTERMINATOR."             In the Pretest, stop is often chosen as the meaning of EX-   TERMINATE. EXTERMINATE is a much stronger         word than stop, however. To EXTERMINATE means to       destroy completely.             Other forms of the word: EXTERMINATION, n.        EXTERMINATOR, n.

to fall behind, fail to keep up     To LAG is to go too slow, to fail to keep up the pace. "All the runners kept on going, but Jim was tired and    LAGGED behind."             "The two of us LAGGED behind the others so that we    could talk some more."           Sometimes LAG is used to mean "to weaken little by lit-    tle, to become less active."          "After a while his interest in history began to LAG."     Usage: LAG is often followed by behind.

deadly, mortal, disastrous         FATE is the influence or power that is supposed to con-    trol our lives. FATAL is an adjective from FATE. See -al    under Suffixes. The basic meaning of FATAL is "deter-      mining one's FATE." The word is generally used about      death, which is everyone's FATE. A FATAL accident is      one that causes death; a FATAL dose of a drug is one   large enough to bring about death. Sometimes the word is     used about things that are so bad or disastrous that they    seem deadly.             "This one FATAL mistake caused many problems for       her later on."            A FATALITY is a death, usually one caused by an acci-    dent or a disaster.           "The police reported seven FATALITIES on the icy       highway that night."            Other forms of the word: FATE, n.        FATALITY, n.

a curse, evil spell, jinx       A HEX is an evil spell, a curse that a witch might put on someone.              "When the machine kept breaking down, it began to      look as though someone had put a HEX on it."     "There must be a HEX on those people; everything      they do turns out wrong."          HEX can also be used as a verb.       "Dave thought that if anyone even mentioned losing it      might somehow HEX the team."

a pretender, faker, fraud        An IMPOSTOR is a person who pretends to be someone     he is not.            "The man said he was from the F.B.I., but he turned    out to be an IMPOSTOR."          "The doctor knew so little about medicine that we ac-     cused him of being an IMPOSTOR."         "It would be impossible for an IMPOSTOR to fool us."

gloomy, sad, dejected         GLUM is related to the word gloom. Someone who is     GLUM is in low spirits; he is in a silent, unhappy mood.   "The student looked very GLUM as he waited in the     principal's office."             "The GLUM athletes sat silently in the locker room      after losing the game."           "Our mailman always looks GLUM. I don't think he      likes his job."

fierce, savage, cruel,         violently aggressive             FEROCIOUS is used about animals and people and the      way they act. It means "extremely cruel, wild, and sav-     age."              "The dog was small but FEROCIOUS: it would attack      dogs three times its size."          "The FEROCIOUS battle lasted all day, with neither       side giving an inch."           The noun from FEROCIOUS is FEROCITY.         "The FEROCITY of his criticism surprised us; we       didn't think he had disliked it that much."       "His FEROCITY when he was angry made everyone       afraid of him."            Other forms of the word: FEROCITY, n.

the inside          See in-1 under Prefixes. The INTERIOR of something is      its inside.             "She liked the house from the outside, but thought its     INTERIOR was very ugly."           "He traveled from the coast to the INTERIOR of the     country."              An "INTERIOR decorator" is a person who decorates the      insides of houses and buildings.          The opposite of INTERIOR is exterior, the outside.       Decoration is often chosen as the meaning of INTERIOR.      People who pick decoration have probably heard the       phrase INTERIOR decoration but don't know exactly        what it means.

price, cost, spending         The EXPENSE of something is how much it costs, how     much you have to pay for it. This cost is usually calcu-   lated in terms of money.          "I want that car, no matter what the EXPENSE."      "He worried about the EXPENSE of the trip."       EXPENSE can refer to other things besides money.       "He stayed outside in the snowstorm, at great EX-      PENSE to his health"-that is, he paid the price for     staying outside by becoming sick.          "We managed to finish the project, but it required a     tremendous EXPENSE of time and energy."         Something that is EXPENSIVE causes EXPENSE-         costs a lot of money or more than it is worth.    "This car is too EXPENSIVE; I have to find one that    costs less."             Other forms of the word: EXPEND, v.        EXPENSIVE, adj.

merry, joyous, glad         GLEE is joy, especially joy caused by triumph or success.     "He shouted with GLEE as they called out his name as    the winner."             GLEEFUL means "full of GLEE."          "He was GLEEFUL at the news that he had been ac-    cepted at college."            "The GLEEFUL child got onto her new bicycle."       Excited is a common choice as the meaning of GLEE-     FUL. A GLEEFUL person will usually be excited, but      GLEEFUL has to do with joy and happiness, not with ex-    citement.              Other forms of the word: GLEE, n.

exercise_1.tfprompt: Would a DEVOTED musician enjoy playing music?
Are the CIRCUMSTANCES of a decision the results of it?
Would most students like to have summer vacations ABOLISHED?
Are you DECEASED?
Can cats DOZE?
Would a baby BAWL if it hadn't been fed for a day?
Was Abraham Lincoln ASSASSINATED?
Would a coach ENCOURAGE his team to win?
Would most people find it CONVENIENT to go to school next door to where they live?
Would most people want to buy a DEFECTIVE watch?
Can ideas be CIRCULATED?
Can an ENCOUNTER be friendly?
Do children usually have AUTHORITY over their parents?
Are all DEFORMED people evil?

exercise_2.tfprompt: No one could match the lawyer's DEVOTION to the cause of justice for all.
These are not the properCIRCUMSTANCES in which to discuss your       problems.
The teacher ABOLISHED them not to talk so loud.
The children always became very sad when they spoke about their DECEASED     uncle.
She DOZED the baby by singing softly to it.
Pete lost his balance and BAWLED down the stairs.
The ASSASSIN followed his victim for days before killing him.
We were ENCOURAGED by the favorable response to our request.
It costs more, but Mrs. Jones likes the CONVENIENCE of having her groceries    delivered right to her door.
There was only one DEFECT in the engine, but it was enough to keep the car from running.
He CIRCULATED the right answer with his pencil and went on to the next   question.
A quick ENCOUNTER showed that we were missing six dollars.
Who gave you the AUTHORITY to close the school?
Larry DEFORMED his letters the way the teacher taught him to.
Everyone on the team was CONFIDENT that we would win.

definitions.deftext: faithfulness, dedication,         loyalty             Someone who is DEVOTED is attached or dedicated to a    purpose, cause, or person.          "They are DEVOTED to the idea of world peace."     DEVOTION is the quality of being DEVOTED; it is     faithfulness, dedication, loyalty.           "Everyone admired her DEVOTION to her sick       parents."             "He was fired because he didn't show enough DEVO-     TION to his duties."          Other forms of the word: DEVOTE, v.       DEVOTED, adj.

a condition,         fact             CIRCUMSTANCES are the conditions or facts surround-       ing some event or situation.         "I cannot make a decision about this until I know all   the CIRCUMSTANCES."            "We were unaware of the terrible CIRCUMSTANCES       at his home; both parents were ill and there was no   food in the house."          "Each CIRCUMSTANCE must be taken into account       before we decide what to do."        "She died under mysterious CIRCUMSTANCES."         Usage: CIRCUMSTANCE is generally used in the plural:      CIRCUMSTANCES.

to do away with, end      To ABOLISH something is to put an end to it or to do away with it. The word is used especially about laws, cus-   toms, and practices rather than about physical objects.      "President Lincoln ABOLISHED slavery in America."        "Our family voted to ABOLISH the tradition of giving     expensive gifts on birthdays."          "Will mankind ever ABOLISH war?"         The noun from ABOLISH is ABOLITION.        "The student council voted for the ABOLITION of the     dress code. They said students should wear whatever      they like."            Other forms of the word: ABOLITION, n.

dead          DECEASED means dead. It is used only about people,     and often refers to someone who is recently dead.     "The DECEASED man's will was read to his relatives     a month after he died."         "Al Johnson is now DECEASED, but he was once the    richest man in town."          DECEASED is also a noun and means the dead person.    "The wishes of the DECEASED must be respected in     this matter."

to sleep lightly        To DOZE is to fall into a light sleep.     "He DOZED for a while, then awoke with a start and   realized he had missed the TV show."       "I must have DOZED off while doing my homework."     DOZE is also a noun.         "The speech was so boring Joan fell into a DOZE after   the first few minutes."          Usage: DOZE is often followed by off.

to cry loudly, shout       To BAWL means "to cry or shout loudly and continu-    ously." Babies BAWL; animals BAWL; children who are      very unhappy BAWL.           "We could hear the baby BAWLING in the next     room."             "The cattle in the stockyard BAWLED in fear and     confusion."             When you get "BAWLED out" you get a loud scolding;    someone shouts at you for doing something wrong.      "Her mother BAWLED her out for coming home late."

a murderer, killer        An ASSASSIN is a murderer or killer, especially one who    is paid for killing or who kills a public official.    "They caught the ASSASSIN of the president."       "The ASSASSIN prepared very carefully to murder       his victim."            The verb from ASSASSIN is ASSASSINATE, which       means to murder or kill.         "Several Roman emperors were ASSASSINATED."         "The madman ASSASSINATED the mayor."         Other forms of the word: ASSASSINATE, v.       ASSASSINATION, n.

to put courage into,       urge on, stimulate, hearten, foster         See in-1 under Prefixes. ENCOURAGE basically means       "to put courage into."          "The soldiers needed to be ENCOURAGED before the      battle."             As the word is used today it means to urge or help some- one to do something, through words or example or in    some other way.           "Her presence ENCOURAGED him to try again."       "My parents ENCOURAGED me to be a doctor."      What is ENCOURAGED can be either good or bad.     "His early success ENCOURAGED him in his life of     crime."             It doesn't have to be a person who is ENCOURAGED.    "The plan was designed to ENCOURAGE small       businesses."             Other forms of the word: ENCOURAGEMENT, n.       ENCOURAGING, adj.

handy, useful,         suitable             Something that is CONVENIENT is near at hand or easy    to use. It is well suited for your comfort or ease.   "He found a CONVENIENT spot near the river and     pitched his tent there."          "I don't care when you come. Pick the time that is   most CONVENIENT for you."          "The soap comes in a CONVENIENT new package      that we're sure you'll like."         The noun from CONVENIENT is CONVENIENCE.        "He arranged the schedule for his own CONVE-      NIENCE. He didn't care if it caused problems for     other people."            Other forms of the word: CONVENIENCE, n.

a fault, flaw, imperfection       A DEFECT is something wrong or damaged, a fault.     "The DEFECT in the jacket was hardly noticeable. It     was just a tiny hole near the button."      "The DEFECT in his plan was that there was no way   we could get the money to carry it out."     "He admitted that his quick temper was a DEFECT in    his character."            The adjective from DEFECT is DEFECTIVE. DEFEC-       TIVE means damaged, "having flaws or faults."       "The lamp was DEFECTIVE: sometimes it would       light and sometimes it wouldn't."         "We didn't realize the air conditioner was DEFEC-      TIVE until we tried to use it."       Other forms of the word: DEFECTIVE, adj.

to move around, spread,       flow freely            -             CIRCULATE is related to the word circle. It means "to    move around and around."          "Blood CIRCULATES in our bodies; it takes about      ten minutes for a complete cycle."        "We could hear the water CIRCULATING in the      pipes."             CIRCULATE also means "to go freely from one place to    another," to spread. In this sense the word can be used   about ideas, information, and the like.        "The news of her arrival CIRCULATED through the      waiting crowd within a few moments."        "They CIRCULATED a petition asking that there be      less homework on the weekends."         Other forms of the word: CIRCULATION, n.

a chance meeting; a       battle, conflict            An ENCOUNTER is a meeting, especially a face-to-face      meeting. There are two different uses of ENCOUNTER.      The first is for any casual, unplanned meeting.      "John had an unexpected ENCOUNTER with his old      friend yesterday."            The second and more common use is for a sudden and   perhaps violent coming together of enemies.        "The bloody ENCOUNTER left six men injured."       ENCOUNTER is also used as a verb, and means to come   upon, meet, confront.           "The two old enemies ENCOUNTERED each other in      the middle of the battle."

power, right         AUTHORITY is the power or right to make people do    something.             ''He received the AUTHORITY to collect taxes in his     district."             "The AUTHORITY of the laws was disregarded by      the rebels."            "As they grew older, Mrs. Smith's children resisted her     AUTHORITY more and more."          Another meaning of AUTHORITY is "a person who has     expert knowledge of something."          "He became the AUTHORITY on the development of      young children."            "She is an AUTHORITY on Shakespeare."

disfigured, misshappen         To DEFORM something is to take it out of its natural   form or shape. See de- under Prefixes. When something is    DEFORMED, then, it is not shaped properly; it is disfig-    ured.             "His leg was DEFORMED as a result of the accident."    "The baby survived, but it was permanently DE-      FORMED."             DEFORMED usually suggests something that is ugly or      offensive.             "When he was very upset, his face would become DE-    FORMED with rage."           In the Pretest, many people choose destroyed as the     meaning of DEFORMED. Something that is DE-       I<'ORMED still exists, it is just misshapen; it has not been   destroyed.             Other forms of the word: DEFORM, v.       DEFORMITY, n.

sure, assured         Someone who is CONFIDENT firmly believes that he is     right or that he can do something. He doesn't have any   fears or doubts about himself.         "I am CONFIDENT that I will succeed. No one can    stop me now."           "She was CONFIDENT she had passed the exam, but     she hadn't expected an A."         "The salesman walked CONFIDENTLY up to them       and told them why they should buy this car."     A person who is CONFIDENT has CONFIDENCE.       "Every success he had gave him a little more CONFI-    DENCE that he could do the job."       "All Jim lacks is CONFIDENCE. He just doesn't think     he's good enough."           The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is myster-      ious. This may be because CONFIDENT looks like confi-     dential, which means secret.          Other forms of the word: CONFIDENCE, n.

exercise_1.tfprompt: Does a penny REPRESENT a lot of money?
Does a horse usually run faster when the rider LASHES it?
Can you RELY on a liar to tell the truth?
Can you SOB while holding you breath?
Do nervous people sometimes PACE back and forth?
Is there more than one METHOD for learning how to swim?
Do soldiers ever RETREAT?
Should people drive cars RECKLESSLY?
Are turtles SWIFT?
Is it possible to REGAIN something you never had?
Do most people have an OPPORTUNITY to go to the moon?
Can a fly buzzing around a person's head be IRRITATING?
Is it more polite to REQUEST something than to demand it?
Do models POSE for pictures?
Do astronomers INVESTIGATE the stars?

exercise_2.tfprompt: That ambassador REPRESENTS Canada.
The angry man LASHED out at everyone who criticized him.
Blanche said that she had always RELIED on the kindness of strangers.
She SOBBEDwith laughter at the funny jokes.
He was going at such a fast PACE that no one could keep up with him.
It seems that every week someone comes up with a new METHOD for teaching   arithmetic.
The soldiers RETREATED to attack the enemy.
He is very RECKLESS about his health; he.eats too much, smokes too much,    and drinks too much.
Bob SWIFTLY recovered the fumble and raced for a touchdown.
It took several weeks for him to REGAIN confidence in his driving ability after   the terrible accident.
He just never had the OPPORTUNITIES to succeed that we have had.
The rash on her arm was further IRRITATED by her constant scratching.
He REQUESTED that we stop talking.
She wore beautiful POSES around her neck.
He INVESTIGATED the possibility of buying a new car.

definitions.deftext: to stand for, act for,       portray              To REPRESENT something is to stand for it, to be a pic-   ture or sign of it.          "The flag is a symbol that REPRESENTS our       country."              "These written notes REPRESENT musical sounds."         "The scenery in the play is supposed to REPRESENT      an African jungle."            To REPRESENT also means to speak or act for someone     or something.             "Bill will REPRESENT our school at the track meet."      "Senator Jones REPRESENTS our state in Con-        gress."              Other forms of the word: REPRESENTATION, n.        REPRESENTATIVE, adj.

to strike, whip, beat        To LASH someone is to hit him with a whip, or as if with a whip.             "He LASHED the thief twenty times for punishment."       "He LASHED the horse with his whip."        "The rain LASHED against the windows."         To give someone a "tongue-LASHING" is to speak to him     very angrily, to make him feel as if you were LASHING    him with a whip. To LASH out at someone is to attack   him violently, with words or blows.         "In his talk the coach LASHED out at the players who    didn't try."

to depend, trust, have faith       To RELY on or upon someone is to depend on him, to   put your trust in him.          "I RELIED on him to help me out."       "We're RELYING on you to keep our secret."       "He can be RELIED on to get us to the airport on   time."              The noun form of RELY is RELIANCE, which means      trust, confidence.             "We place our RELIANCE on you to get us out of    trouble."              The adjective is RELIABLE. Someone who is RELI-       ABLE can be RELIED upon.          "He is a RELIABLE worker. You can count on him to    do the job right."           Other forms of the word: RELIABLE, adj.        RELIANCE, n.             Usage: RELY is usually followed by on or upon.

to cry, weep         To SOB is to cry in gasping bursts, while taking sharp    breaths.              "She SOBBED in relief that the child was not in-     jured."              "We heard him SOBBING quietly in his room."       SOB is also a noun.          "We couldn't understand what the unhappy child was       saying as she tried to talk between SOBS."       "The first angry crying gave way to long SOBS."      "His chest heaved with SOBS."

a step; rate of moving       A PACE is a step in walking or running.      "He took a PACE or two and then stopped."      It is also the distance of a step.       "She measured off six PACES from the tree."       The word is also used to indicate the rate of walking or   moving.              "He worked at a steady PACE all day long."      "He changed his PACE and started to run instead of     walk."              PACE is also a verb meaning to step or walk.     "He PACED back and forth across the room."

a way, manner, system        A METHOD is an orderly, logical way of doing some-     thing.              "There are several METHODS for teaching words."        "His METHOD for doing jigsaw puzzles is quite dif-      ferent from my system."           "It takes days to learn the right METHOD for operat-     ing this machine."            A METHODICAL person does everything in an orderly       way, according to a METHOD. He always thinks things      through before acting.            "He was very METHODICAL about dressing. He put       everything on in a certain order and in a certain     way."              Other forms of the word: METHODICAL, adj.

to go back, draw back, withdraw      To RETREAT is to go back, especially from a dangerous     or difficult situation.            "When the enemy attacked, the army was forced to      RETREAT."              "If we RETREAT, will people think we are cowards?"      RETREAT is also a noun.          "The general said that a RETREAT was the only way     to save the army."

careless, heedless, rash, fool-        hardy, wild             See -less under Suffixes. RECK is an old word which     means to take care, be concerned. Someone who is      RECKLESS does not take enough care, is thoughtless or      wild.              "The RECKLESS driver went down the narrow street       at a hundredmiles per hour."          "He raced after the criminal, completely RECKLESS        of the danger."            "She lost everything she owned through her RECK-       LESS gambling."             Usage: RECKLESS is sometimes followed by of.

fast, quick, prompt         SWIFT means fast or quick; the word usually suggests      smoothness of movement.            "We had all we could do to keep from overturning in    the SWIFT waters of the river."         "He ran so SWIFTLY that the others never caught up     with him."             "The days of summer pass SWIFTLY and the vaca-      tion is over before you know it."        "There was a SWIFT change in the weather from blue     skies to heavy rain."

to get back, recover        See re- under Prefixes. To REGAIN something is to gain     it or get it back after you have lost it. The word is usually used about qualities or states rather than physical ob-      jects.              "After being in prison for ten years, he finally RE-     GAINED his freedom."            "It took Jane a while to REGAIN her health after her    operation."              "They lost the lead, then REGAINED it."        "He REGAINED his balance after nearly slipping on       the ice."

a chance          An OPPORTUNITY is a favorable time or chance for do-     ing something.             "This is a golden OPPORTUNITY for making all       kinds of money."            "If I only had the OPPORTUNITY I'd show them      what a good player I am."         "We had plenty of OPPORTUNITIES to win. We just      couldn't seem to take advantage of them."        "Jane had no OPPORTUNITY to speak to the teacher      after school."             Usage: OPPORTUNITY is often followed by to or for.

to annoy, cause anger; to       make sore, inflame            See -ate2 under Suffixes. IRRITATE has two different       meanings. To IRRITATE someone is to cause him to be-     come angry, to annoy him.          "The student's endless questions quickly IRRITATED         the impatient teacher."            "After several weeks, Jane found her roommate's        sloppy habits to be extremely IRRITATING."         "The mother was very IRRITATED by her children's       constant whining."             In another sense, to IRRITATE something is to cause it     to become sore or inflamed.          "The woman's eyes were IRRITATED by the smoke-       filled air."             IRRITABLE is the adjective from IRRITATE and means       bad-tempered.              "Hot weather always made him very IRRITABLE, and       on those days we tried our best to avoid him."     Other forms of the word: IRRITABLE, adj.        IRRITATION, n.

to ask, ask for        To REQUEST something is to ask for it, usually very po-    litely.              "He REQUESTED a new pair of shoes from his par-     ents."              "I REQUESTED him to come early."         "All I REQUEST of you is that you be on time."    "They REQUEST that we be silent until they are fin-     ished."              REQUEST is also a noun.          "At their REQUEST we shall come to the party."      "They turned down his REQUEST for a raise."

a position of the body, attitude      A POSE is a fixed position of the body, especially one    that is taken up while your picture is being taken or    painted.              "He had an odd POSE in the painting, leaning to the    side with one foot in the air."        POSE has also come to mean any way of behaving which    may seem unnatural or put on just to impress people.     "She acted very friendly towards us, but it was all just    a POSE. Really she disliked us intensely."        As a verb, POSE means "to hold a physical position."     "His wife used to POSE for his paintings."       It can also mean "to take on a false character, to claim to  be."              "The robber POSED as a janitor in order to get into    the apartment."

to look into, exam-        ine in detail, study           INVESTIGATE comes from the Latin word for footprint.       The word was used in Latin when talking about tracking     down animals by following their footprints. In English, to      INVESTIGATE something is to make careful study of it,      to look into it closely.          "The policeman INVESTIGATED the crime."          "We will have to INVESTIGATE how much a new ra-     dio costs."             "He INVESTIGATED the area for clues."         Many people confuse the meaning of INVESTIGATE        with the word prove. You might INVESTIGATE a crime,      for example, to prove who did it, but INVESTIGATE      only means to look into or study.        Other forms of the word: INVESTIGATION, n.

exercise_1.tfprompt: Should children be MISTREATED?
Are happy people usually FURIOUS?
Would you need to use CAUTION if you were walking on a tightrope?
Is 4 a greater QUANTITY than 3?
Have you EXPIRED?
Do most people favor the ELIMINATION of war?
Does a BANDIT break the law?
Are TIRESOME people fun to be with?
Are there NUMEROUS stars in the sky?
Are the stars DISTANT from Earth?
Can people live at a low ALTITUDE?
Is a summer job a PERMANENT one?
Is there a BORDER between the United States and Canada?
When you buy a book, does it usually have to be ASSEMBLED?
Would a six-foot-wide potato be PECULIAR?

exercise_2.tfprompt: Her mother MISTREATED her to another piece of cake after supper.
Bill gets FURIOUS whenever anyone is late for an appointment with him.
He CAUTIOUSLY avoided going near the large dog.
We don't care if we make a smaller QUANTITY of chairs, as long as the quality remains good.
His library card EXPIRED six months ago.
They tried to ELIMINATE her from the race because she was too young.
BANDITS of armed men wandered through the streets of the deserted city.
He was so TIRESOME after the long trip that he fell asleep right away.
He was NUMEROUS last night.
We could barely see them on the DISTANT hill.
Jim grew to an ALTITUDE of well over six feet.
This was supposed to be our PERMANENT home, but we moved again after a   few years.
Soldiers patrolled the BORDER between the two countries.
They ASSEMBLED each other so much we thought they were twins.
This fish is PECULIAR to the Pacific Ocean.

definitions.deftext: to treat badly, abuse       See mis- under Prefixes. To MISTREAT someone is to     treat him badly, to do wrong to him, either physically or   in some other way.          "Look at all the cuts on that dog. I think his owner  MISTREATS him."            "Alice complained that she had been MISTREATED       by her teachers."           "The parents were accused of MISTREATING their       children by not giving them enough to eat."      Cheat is often chosen as the meaning of MISTREAT on    the Pretest. MISTREAT is a much more general word     than cheat, however. You can MISTREAT a person by     doing wrong to him in any way, not just by cheating him.  Other forms of the word: MISTREATMENT, n.

angry, violent, stormy,        fierce             FURY is violent anger.          "The mother was filled with FURY when she saw them    hurting her child."           FURIOUS is the adjective from FURY. See -ous under     Suffixes. Someone who is FURIOUS is full of wild anger.    "Her father was FURIOUS when Jill wrecked his car."     "She was mildly upset, but everyone else was really     FURIOUS."             FURIOUS also means "full of activity," wild, energetic.      "He put on a FURIOUS finish to come from behind    and win the race."          "With one FURIOUS burst of activity, they com-      pletelycleaned the house in two hours."        Other forms of the ford: FURY, n.

careful, watchful         To be CAUTIOUS is to be careful, to pay close attention   so that you don't make a mistake or so that you don't hurt anyone.             "You must be CAUTIOUS when you cross a busy     street."             "She patted the kitten CAUTIOUSLY so that it      wouldn't become alarmed and run away."        "The burglar made a CAUTIOUS approach to the      darkened house."            CAUTION is the noun from CAUTIOUS; it means care,     alertness.             "You must use CAUTION when dealing with poisons."      "He answered with a great deal of CAUTION. He was    afraid to say something he didn't mean."       Other forms of the word: CAUTION, n., v.

an amount, number        QUANTITY is something that can be measured. When      you ask "How much?" or "How many?" you are asking    about the QUANTITY of something.         "There is a large QUANTITY of dog food left over."    "We need a small QUANTITY of nails to build this    bookcase."             Many people pick value as the meaning of QUANTITY.     This is probably due to a confusion between QUANTITY     and quality. Quality has to do with how good something    IS.             "We're not interested in quality but in QUANTITY.      We don't care how good they are as long as there are a lot of them."

to die, come to an end, cease    See ex- under Prefixes. EXPIRE originally meant "to      breathe out." From this it has come to mean "to breathe   one's last," to die. When used about people the word al-   ways means to die.          "After a long illness, he EXPIRED early this morn-     ing."             When used about things it means to end or cease.    "The contract will EXPIRE at midnight"-that is, it      will no longer be in effect after that time.     "The senator's term of office will EXPIRE next year."     Other forms of the word: EXPIRATION, n.

to remove, get rid of,      throw out, take away          ELIMINATE comes from a Latin word which means "to     throw out of doors," and this is the original meaning of   the word. See ex- under Prefixes. Today the word simply    means to throw out or get rid of, and doesn't necessarily   mean to throw something outside.         "The doctors found a new medicine that completely      ELIMINATED the disease."           "The judges ELIMINATED him from the contest."       The noun form of ELIMINATE is ELIMINATION. An      "ELIMINATION tournament" is one in which the loser      of a game or match is removed from the competition.    Other forms of the word: ELIMINATION, n.

a robber, outlaw        A BANDIT was originally a member of a gang of people   who banded together in order to rob. Now BANDIT is    used about anyone who robs people, alone or as part of a  gang.             "He was held up by a BANDIT in broad daylight."    "The BANDITS fled to a cabin in the hills."

boring, tedious, dull, an-       noying             Something that is TIRESOME makes you tired. The      word is usually used about people or things that are so   boring they make you want to fall asleep. The word, how-   ever, does not mean tired; it means causing tiredness.     "Having to write the same sentence fifty times is an    extremely TIRESOME exercise."           "Jim can make exciting events seem TIRESOME."       Sometimes TIRESOME suggests the meaning annoying        more than boring.           "She was a very TIRESOME person to deal with, al-    ways whining and complaining."

nyU-m�r-�s) adj.:         many             NUMEROUS comes from the Latin word for number.      The word means "great in number," many. See -ous un-    der Suffixes.            "There are NUMEROUS reasons why we can't come. I     will only tell you a few."        "NUMEROUS people applied for the job, but only one     would get it."           "The people who helped me are too NUMEROUS to     mention."             "NUMEROUS colleges want our star quarterback to       play for them."

far off         DISTANT means far off, far away.        "Jim wanted to leave home and travel to DISTANT     lands."             "The sound of DISTANT church bells came faintly to     us."             "The sun is 93 million miles DISTANT from the     Earth."             DISTANT can be used about time as well as space.    "In the DISTANT past people lived in caves and not    in houses."            Other forms of the word: DISTANCE, n.

height          ALTITUDE means height. It is used about things, not     people.             "The planes rose to an ALTITUDE of 20,000 feet     above sea level."           "The city is located in the mountains at an ALTI-    TUDE of 5,000 feet."          "At this ALTITUDE it becomes very difficult to      breathe."             The ALTITUDE of something can be described as either     high or low.           "He flew the helicopter at a very low ALTITUDE as    he tried to spot where the plane had crashed."

lasting, unchanging         PERMANENT means lasting, "meant to be the same for     a long time."           "This is only my summer home; my PERMANENT      home is in New York City."        "After several temporary jobs, he got a PERMANENT      job in the post office."         "He received a PERMANENT injury from the acci-      dent."             "The dentist put a PERMANENT filling in the pa-     tient's tooth."            Other forms of the word: PERMANENCE, n.

edge, boundary, frontier        BORDER has many meanings and uses, but the main one    is the edge of something.         "There was a BORDER of gold around the invitation."     A BORDER is a boundary between two countries.      "We crossed the BORDER into Canada late in the af-    ternoon."             "You have to stop at the BORDER and show your    passport."             BORDER is also a verb which means "to lie along or be  adjacent to the BORDER of."         "Our farm BORDERS the state highway."        "The city is BORDERED by the ocean to the east."

to bring together, gather       together             ASSEMBLE means to bring together or gather together.      The word usually suggests an orderly gathering of people     with a common purpose.          "The troops were ASSEMBLED on the parade       ground."             "The senators will ASSEMBLE tomorrow to vote on      the new law."           ASSEMBLE can also mean to put together.       "It took us three days to ASSEMBLE the jigsaw puz-    zle."             "He thinks he can ASSEMBLE a new car from the    parts of old ones."          Other forms of the word: ASSEMBLY, n.

odd, strange, different,        unusual; unique, characteristic           PECULIAR means odd, strange, "different from anyone       or anything else."           "He had a PECULIAR way of talking that no one else   could imitate."            "It was very PECULIAR that everyone was absent on     the same day."           Another meaning of PECULIAR is "belonging only to one     person, group, place, or the like." In this sense PECU-    LIAR is usually followed by to.        "This kind of house is PECULIAR to New England.     You won't find it anywhere else."        Other forms of the word: PECULIARITY, n.

definitions.deftext: to breathe out        See ex- under Prefixes. To EXHALE is to breathe out.    "He took a deep breath, then EXHALED slowly."      "He EXHALED the air from his lungs."       The opposite of EXHALE is INHALE, to breathe in.     Other forms of the word: EXHALATION, n.

to jump over, overcome, sur-      mount             A HURDLE is an obstacle that you jump over in certain   running races. To HURDLE something is to jump over it    the way a runner would jump over a HURDLE.     "With one tremendous leap, the horse HURDLED the      high fence."            You can HURDLE any kind of obstacle or barrier.     "If we can HURDLE this final problem the project will    be a success."           "Students had to HURDLE a difficult series of tests     before they were admitted to the school."       HURDLE is sometimes confused with hurtle, which       means "to move with great speed."        "He hurtled down the mountside, HURDLING sev-       eral fallen trees along the way."

to protect, guard        To DEFEND something is to protect it, to keep it from   harm.             "The high wall DEFENDS the city against its ene-     mies."             "His friends DEFENDED him when he was being at-     tacked."             You can DEFEND someone from other things besides      physical harm.            "The teacher DEFENDED Bill's right to say what was     on his mind."           The act of DEFENDING is called DEFENSE.       "In DEFENSE of their kittens, mother cats will attack     much larger animals."           "The government spends a great deal of money for the    DEFENSE of the country."          Other forms of the word: DEFENSE, n.

danger, risk, peril        Originally HAZARD was a game of chance using dice.     HAZARD has come to be used about anything that has a   chance of being harmful, a possible source of danger or in-   jury.             "The ice on the roads is a real HAZARD to drivers."   "The building inspector said that the loose electrical      wires were a HAZARD."          The adjective from HAZARD is HAZARDOUS, danger-       ous, risky.            "Cigarette smoking is HAZARDOUS to your health."       "Going over Niagara Falls in a barrel is certainly a    HAZARDOUS feat."            Other forms of the word: HAZARDOUS, adj.

to burst forth, explode, break out     To ERUPT is to burst forth, suddenly and usually vio-    lently. See ex- underPrefixes. When a volcano ERUPTS,      steam and lava pour out of it.       "A cheer ERUPTED from the crowd when we scored     the winning touchdown."           "Her face ERUPTS in a raeh whenever she eats straw-    berries."             "Hal kept his anger under control all day, but it finally   ERUPTED at something Ann said."         An ERUPTION is an outburst or an explosion.      "The sudden ERUPTION of fighting between the two      countries surprised everyone."           Other forms of the word: ERUPTION, n.

to hide, keep secret       To CONCEAL something is to hide it from sight.     "Ann CONCEALED the letter under her pillow."       "He CONCEALED his face with a mask."       "Several large trees CONCEALED the house from       view."             You can also CONCEAL ideas, plans, conditions, facts,      and so on.           "He cleverly CONCEALED his real opinion by agree-      ing with everything we said."         "It was impossible to CONCEAL the truth from her.     She guessed it right away."         Other forms of the word: CONCEALMENT, n.

v.: to redden, become red      BLUSH means to redden or to become red. When people    BLUSH, their faces become red, usually because they are     embarrassed or ashamed.           "David BLUSHED as he accepted the award for being     the top student."           "She tries hard to appear calm, but whenever she     meets him she BLUSHES."          BLUSH is also used as a noun.       "Andy covered his face with his hands to hide his    BLUSHES."             "Samantha admitted with a BLUSH that she had      lied."

to look at carefully, search,      inspect, test, question           To EXAMINE something is to look at it carefully in or-   der to find out something about it or to learn from it. You can EXAMINE things.           "He EXAMINED the boat for leaks."        "The dentist EXAMINED his teeth."         Or you can EXAMINE people, by asking questions in-     stead of just looking.          "The lawyer EXAMINED the witness."         "The teacher EXAMINED the students in algebra."       AnEXAMINATION is an act of EXAMINING, a test.      "Did you pass the final EXAMINATION?"        "The luggage underwent a thorough EXAMINA-        TION."             Other forms of the word: EXAMINATION, n.

to build, put together       CONSTRUCT means to build, especially by putting to-      gether parts.            "We are going to CONSTRUCT a small shed in our    backyard for all the gardening equipment."        "That big hotel was CONSTRUCTED in less than six     months."             You can CONSTRUCT other things besides buildings.       "He can CONSTRUCT a kite out of newspaper and     cardboard."             "She CONSTRUCTED her argument very carefully        by putting all the facts together and in order."     Other forms of the word: CONSTRUCTION, n.

a rule, order        A REGULATION is a rule, an order which must be fol-   lowed.             "It says in the school REGULATIONS that you are to    be here by 8:30."          "They were careful to follow all the safety REGULA-     TIONS."             "None of the REGULATIONS covers this particular       problem."             "It is against company REGULATIONS for a worker      to be absent without good reason."        Other forms of the word: REGULATE, v.       REGULATORY, adj.

dirt, soot, dust        GRIME is dirt, especially a coating of dirt on the surface   of something.            "There was a layer of GRIME on the windowsill that    no amount of scrubbing could remove."        "After working in the mine all day his face was covered   with GRIME."            GRIMY means "covered with GRIME," dirty.        "Don't touch that white tablecloth with your GRIMY      hands."             Other forms of the word: GRIMY, adj.

a disadvantage, disabil-        ity             HANDICAP is a term in horse racing. In some races, in   order to make them fairer or more exciting, the faster    horses are given more weight to carry than the slower    horses. This extra weight is called a HANDICAP.      HANDICAP has come into general use, meaning "any      kind of burden or disadvantage which lessens your chance     of success."            "His poor background in mathematics was quite a      HANDICAP when he tried to study engineering."       "She didn't think of her blindness as a HANDICAP;     she thought of it as a challenge to be overcome."    HANDICAP can also be a verb.        "We were HANDICAPPED by our inability to speak      Spanish."

shame, dishonor         See dis- under Prefixes. One meaning of grace is favor or   goodwill. To be in someone's "good graces" is to enjoy his   honor and approval. DISGRACE is a lack of grace; it is   shame or dishonor.           "His crimes brought DISGRACE on his entire family."      A DISGRACE is also the thing or person that causes the   shame.             "That worker is a DISGRACE to the company. He     should be fired."           Something which is DISGRACEFUL causes DISGRACE.        "Your conduct is DISGRACEFUL. You should be       ashamed of yourself."           Other forms of the word: DISGRACEFUL, adj.

to lure, entice; to attack, tease, harass    BAIT is related to the word bite. BAIT as a noun is food, or something like food, put on a hook to attract a fish. As a verb, BAIT has developed two different meanings. To     BAIT someone can be to lure him the way a fish is lured, by holding out something to tempt him.       "The phony message BAITED the enemy into attack-      ing us just where we wanted them to."      To BAIT is also to torment, annoy, or harass, usually in   speech or writing.           "An angry woman in the crowd BAITED the speaker     until he lost his temper."         "The other team BAITED us the whole game about     our poor record."

magnificent, grand, excel-        lent             SPLENDID comes from a Latin word meaning to shine.     Something that is SPLENDID shines out; it is brilliant or    magnificent.             "She looked SPLENDID in her fancy new gown."      "This is a SPLENDID book. I recommend it highly."     "We had a SPLENDID opportunity to score, but we     weren't able to."           The noun from SPLENDID is SPLENDOR. SPLEN-       DOR is magnificence or excellence.         "We were amazed by the SPLENDOR of every room     in the palace."           Other forms of the word: SPLENDOR, n.

definitions.deftext: to copy, follow the example of,     try to be like          To IMITATE something is to try to be like it, to copy it. You can IMITATE a person or a thing.      "He tried to IMITATE the sound of a duck."     "She wants to IMITATE the figure skaters she sees on    television."             An IMITATION is something that is a copy of something    else.             "The building is an IMITATION of an ancient Greek     temple."             "He did a funny IMITATION of a man slipping on a   banana peel."            Other forms of the word: IMITATION, n.

to twist about, wiggle, wriggle      To SQUIRM means "to twist the body about," to wiggle    or wriggle.            "The baby SQUIRMED so much I almost dropped      him."             "He's trying to SQUIRM through the cellar window."      People often twist about when they feel uncomfortable or     embarrassed, and SQUIRM is also used to express this     sense.             "Try not to SQUIRM in your chair while I introduce    you to my uncle."

friendly, liking compa-        ny, companionable-            SOCIABLE means "liking the company of other people,"      friendly. A SOCIABLE person just naturally likes to be     with other people, even if they are strangers.      "They are a SOCIABLE couple, always inviting       friends over."            "We played a SOCIABLE game of poker."       "We always enjoy the company of SOCIABLE       people."             SOCIABLE is the opposite of hostile or unfriendly. You     cannot, for example, have a SOCIABLE fight.

to gain, accomplish, get       ACHIEVE means to gain or to get, often with some de-   gree of difficulty.           "He ACHIEVED his goal of learning to walk again af-    ter he had been crippled."         "She realized that it was necessary to study to     ACHIEVE an A in math."         "Most of us have to work hard to ACHIEVE any suc-   cess."             The noun from ACHIEVE is ACHIEVEMENT, which       means an accomplishment.           "His greatest ACHIEVEMENT was to score the       winning touchdown."            "She is not content to get by on her previous    ACHIEVEMENTS, but is always looking for new       fields to conquer."           Other for,!lls of the word: ACHIEVEMENT, n.

to be like, look like, act     like             RESEMBLE means "to be like or look like" somebody or    something.             "She RESEMBLES her mother, particularly around        the eyes."            "The twins don't RESEMBLE each other at all."      "The son RESEMBLES his father in his patience and     good humor."            The noun from RESEMBLE is RESEMBLANCE.        "The RESEMBLANCE between distant relatives is        often remarkable."            Other forms of the word: RESEMBLANCE, n.

protection, safety         SHELTER is used in two senses. First, it is a building or  place that gives protection.          "After half an hour they reached the ski SHELTER."     "We stood in the bus SHELTER to keep out of the   strong wind."            Second, SHELTER means protection itself.         "We tried to find SHELTER from the heavy rain."     "The family sought SHELTER in their basement from      the bombs."            SHELTER is also used as a verb and means to protect.   "The doorway of the building SHELTERED us from      the storm."            "The beach umbrella SHELTERS us from the burning      sun."

to take, take hold of, seize, clutch; to   understand, comprehend            To GRASP something is to take hold of it.     "He GRASPED the handlebars of his bicycle."       "She GRASPED the cup firmly with both hands so     that it wouldn't fall."          GRASP is also used to mean "to take hold of mentally,"   to understand.            "I fail to GRASP how your plan will help us."    "It took a lot ofexplaining, but finally Jim seemed to    GRASP the idea."

to trip, walk unsteadily,       make a mistake -          To STUMBLE is to trip and almost fall, often as the re-  sult of hitting something that is in your way.     "The hidden wirecaused him to STUMBLE, but he      managed to stay on his feet."        To STUMBLE is also to walk along unsteadily, to stag-    ger, as if you were about to fall at any second.   "The drunk STUMBLED along, barely able to stand      up."             In general use the word can also mean "to speak or act  clumsily," to blunder or /founder.         "Johnny STUMBLED over every word as he tried to     read the sentence."           "We didn't know anything about it, so we just STUM-    BLED along, doing the best we could."

to break         SHATTER means "to break into small pieces." SHAT-      TER is used in connection with glass or anything like    glass that breaks easily.          "The bottle rolled off the table and SHATTERED on     the floor."            "The windshield SHATTERED when the car hit the      tree."             SHATTER can be used in a broader sense about health,    hopes, nerves, and the like.         "His nerves were SHATTERED by the terrible bat-      tle."

to bend down, bow down, lower one-    self             To STOOP is to bend down from the waist.     "Jim STOOPED over to pick up a dime on the floor."   "He STOOPED so that he wouldn't hit his head on the   pipe."             From this physical sense STOOP has come to mean "to    do something that is beneath you" in terms of either rank   or morals.            "How could you STOOP to telling such an awful lie?"    "Why did the famous actor STOOP to doing television     commercials?"

depressed, sad, dis-        -             couraged             The word cast in DOWNCAST means throw, and      DOWNCAST was originally a verb which meant to throw     down or overthrow. Now DOWNCAST is only used as an    adjective to describespirits or looks that are "thrown      down" because something sad has happened.        "We tried to cheer him up because he seemed DOWN-    CAST."             "You look so DOWNCAST. What's wrong?"        "Bobby has a right to be DOWNCAST. His fumble     cost us the game."          "Almost everyone feels DOWNCAST on a gray,       gloomy day."

to spring up, begin to grow, send    out leaves or buds          To SPROUT means to spring up, to begin to grow.    SPROUT is most often used about plants or other grow-    ing things, but it has also come to be used about anything  that grows suddenly or quickly.         "Because of the sudden increase in population, new      towns SPROUTED up almost overnight."         "When he was fourteen his beard began to SPROUT."     SPROUT can also mean "to cause to grow, to send out   new leaves."            "The tree SPROUTED new buds in the spring."      Usage: SPROUT is often followed by up.

to near, come near       APPROACH means to come near or get near.      "We all felt relieved as we watched him APPROACH     us without tripping."           "What is the right way to APPROACH the king's     throne?"             "She was APPROACHING the age to leave home."      APPROACH is also a noun that means a road or way to  something. When APPROACH is used to mean way, it     can be used in either sense of way: a path or a method. "We'll have to use another APPROACH (method) to      get him to agree."          "The APPROACH (path) to the highway was blocked      by snow."

to get back; to become well     To RECOVER something is to get or win it back. See re-  under Prefixes.            "She RECOVERED the ring she had lost."       "They RECOVERED his shoe from the bottom of the     pond."             "You'll never RECOVER all the money you have      wasted."             When a person RECOVERS from something, he gets bet-     ter, becomes well.           "He RECOVERED from the sickness."         "She is fully RECOVERED from her accident."

is the act of getting back or get-   ting better.            "He was pleased by the quick RECOVERY of his lost    wallet."             "Her RECOVERY from the illness will take many      months."             Other forms of the word: RECOVERY, n.

to shorten         To ABBREVIATE something is to make it shorter by     leaving out parts. The word is used particularly when     talking about the shortening of words and phrases.      "The words 'United States of America' are ABBRE-      VIATED to "USA".           "His name was Albert, but he ABBREVIATED it to     Al in order to save space."        ABBREVIATE can be used about other things as well.     "The mayor's speech had to be ABBREVIATED be-      cause we ran out of time."        The noun from ABBREVIATE is ABBREVIATION.        "Mr. is the ABBREVIATION for Mister."        Other forms ofthe word: ABBREVIATION, n.        3.             5.

exercise_1.tfprompt: Do other things besides food DECAY?
Do most people like to be MISERABLE?
Do the leaves of trees TREMBLE when the wind blows through them?
Is an Olympic gold medal a TROPHY?
Are governors ELECTED?
Are some people TERRIFIED of the dark?
Are all TERRITORIES the same size?
If you take frozen food out of the freezer, will it THAW?
Do people usually say "Hello" when they DEPART?
Do people usually HOLLER in the library?
Are people who are watching a baseball game PARTICIPATING in it?
Is someone who learns a language in a few months a RAPID learner?
Would a store usually REFUND your money if you returned an item that you had broken?
Can a wink be a RESPONSE?
Can a piece of paper be SCORCHED?

exercise_2.tfprompt: She DECAYED it until it was all used up.
I'm sorry I hurt you; I didn't mean to make you MISERABLE.
She TREMBLED the cup of coffee onto the floor.
Each year the winning team receives a large TROPHY.
They gave us a choice, so we ELECTED to stay here.
The news that there was no school today filled us all with TERROR.
The explorers came upon a TERRITORY they had never heard of before.
When the temperature dropped below zero, everything began to THAW.
Their DEPARTURE was a sad event for those of us who stayed behind.
She HOLLERED for help when she saw the monster.
They wanted the whole school to PARTICIPATE in selecting a nickname for     the team.
He became very RAPID whenever anyone disagreed with him.
If you mail in this coupon, we will send you a fifty-cent REFUND.
We had to wait three weeks for a RESPONSE to our request for a new tele- phone.
They SCORCHED the sink so that it would be completely clean.

definitions.deftext: to rot, spoil, go bad      DECAY means to rot or go bad, to spoil. The word   usually suggests a slow natural change from a good condi-    tion to a worse one. The word can be used about physical  changes or about the breakdown of the mind, morals, or    the like.            "The applesripened, fell off the tree, and then DE-     CAYED."             "The stink of the DECAYING garbage was overpower-      ing."             "His athletic skills had DECAYED from lack of prac-     tice."             DECAY is also a noun which means rot or ruin-    "In that section of town many old houses were aban-    doned and had fallen into a state of DECAY."     "He brushed his teeth every day to prevent tooth DE-    CAY."

miz'-r�b�I) adj.: un-        happy, wretched, worthless, very uncomfortable         MISERY is a state of suffering and great unhappiness.     "They tried to make her feel better, but no one could   relieve her MISERY."           MISERABLE means "full of MISERY," unhappy. See       -able under Suffixes.           "Her cold made her feel MISERABLE."        "The dog was MISERABLE when its master went      away."             MISERABLE can also mean "causing MISERY,"        wretched.             "This MISERABLE rainy weather has got to end."      "They lived in MISERABLE conditions in the slum."      Other forms of the word: MISERY, n.

to shake,shiver, shudder        TREMBLE means to shake or shiver, because of fear,     cold, anger, or even sickness.         "He was so angry that his voice TREMBLED when he    tried to speak."           "When he came out of the water, his lips were blue   with cold and he TREMBLED all over."       "The needle TREMBLED slightly and then stopped       on zero."

a prize, award        A TROPHY is something that is given to a person in   memory of a victory or a success. It could be a statue, a medal, a cup, or something similar.        "He keeps his bowling TROPHIES in a special cabi-     net."             "The TROPHY for the top student is a plaque with    his or her name on it."

to choose, select by vote, decide upon,    pick out            To ELECT basically means to choose, and is sometimes     used in this way:          "We ELECTED to go home first."        Usually, though, ELECT means "to choose among candi-      dates for a political office."         "When someone is ELECTED president, he is chosen      by the voters to be president."        "Alice was ELECTED class treasurer by fifty-seven       votes."             An ELECTION is an act of choosing. In an ELECTION,    voters choose whom they want to be in office. An ELEC-   TIVE course is one which the student may choose to take,   as opposed to a course which he is required to take.   Other forms of the word: ELECTION, n.       ELECTIVE, adj.

to scare, frighten, fill with fear     To TERRIFY someone is to make him extremely scared     or frightened, to the point where he almost loses his    senses.             "He is TERRIFIED of fire."         "Don't TERRIFY the child with those foolish ghost      stories."             The noun from TERRIFY is TERROR. TERROR is      great fear or horror.          "The sound of the bombs falling filled them with     TERROR."             "The king ruled not by kindness, but by TERROR."     Other forms of the word: TERROR, n.

an area, district, region,       land             A TERRITORY is an area of land belonging to a person   or government. Animals also have TERRITORIES, which       are the areas they consider theirs, and which they will de-   fend against other animals.          "The backyard fence marks the boundary of my cat's     TERRITORY."             "Several tribes held the large TERRITORY in com-      mon."             Districts assigned to traveling salespeople are called       TERRITORIES also.            "Mr. Smith's TERRITORY covers all of New York      state outside of New York City."        Other forms of the word: TERRITORIAL, adj.

to melt, become liquid, become un-     frozen -            THAW means to melt, to become unfrozen.       "It was several weeks before the last of the ice    THAWED."             "I forgot to THAW the meat for supper."      THAW is often used in a broader sense about feelings    that become warmer.           "They had been enemies for years, but finally relations     between them THAWED."           THAW is also a noun.         "After the spring THAW the streets were inches deep     in water."

To DEPART is to go away.        v.: to go away, leave         "They stayed here for three days and then DE-     PARTED."             "Our ship DEPARTS next week."         "We were having such an enjoyable time at the show    that we didn't want to DEPART."        "We DEPARTED from our usual habit of going to bed    early."             The noun from DEPART is DEPARTURE.        "The bad weather delayed the plane's DEPAR-       TURE."             Other forms of the word: DEPARTURE, n.

to yell, shout, cry out      To HOLLER is to shout, to make a loud noise, usually be-  cause you are excited, unhappy, or want to get someone's    attention.             "Sally HOLLERED to her friends across the lake."      "He HOLLERED for help, but no one came."      "He was so afraid that he started to HOLLER when    anyone came near him."          "Don't HOLLER; I can hear you perfectly well."

to take part in,       -             share in            To PARTICIPATE in something is to take part in it. You   can see the word part in PARTICIPATE.       "Everyone must PARTICIPATE in the singing."        "It's hard to play a football game if no one else wants  to PARTICIPATE."            "The teacher asked us to PARTICIPATE in the dis-     cussion."             A PARTICIPANT is someone who PARTICIPATES.        "All the PARTICIPANTS in the show should be con-     gratulated."             Other forms of the word: PARTICIPANT, n.       PARTICIPATION, n.            Usage: PARTICIPATE is usually followed by in.

quick, fast, speedy, swift       RAPID is another word for fast.        "We are making RAPID progress toward solving the      problem."             "The student gave RAPID answers to all of the teach-    er's questions."            "We walked RAPIDLY along the dark street."       The noun from RAPID is RAPIDITY.        "Their RAPIDITY makes it hard for us to keep up    with them."            "We were amazed at the RAPIDITY with which she     solved the problem."           Other forms of the word: RAPIDITY, n.

to pay back, repay, give back     REFUND means to pay back. See re- under Prefixes. It is   usually used when speaking of money.        "If you are not fully satisfied with our product, we will   cheerfully REFUND your money."          "He paid them too much, so they REFUNDED the ex-    tra amount to him."          REFUND is also a noun, meaning a repayment.      "She paid too much in taxes to the government, so    they sent her a REFUND."         When used as a noun, the word is pronounced rE'-fuhnd.

an answer, reply        To RESPOND to something is to say something in re-    turn, to answer.           "When asked about her health, she RESPONDED       that she had never felt better."        RESPONSE is the noun from RESPOND. A RE-      SPONSE is an answer, a reply.        "When the teacher asked who had thrown the pencil,     there was no RESPONSE."          "I asked him if he would go, and his RESPONSE was   that it would depend on the weather."       A RESPONSE doesn't have to be spoken.       "When they asked him a rude question, his RE-     SPONSE was to slam the door in their faces."     Other forms of the word: RESPOND, v.

to burn slightly        To SCORCH something is to burn it slightly, usually just    on the surface. Often something that has been      SCORCHED turns brown or dries up.        "The leaves were SCORCHED by the hot sun."      "He SCORCHED his shirt when he tried to iron it."    "The meat was SCORCHED when she left it in the    oven for too long."          Other forms of the word: SCORCHING, adj.

exercise_1.tfprompt: Does pain usually ACCOMPANY an injury?
Do banks give people PERMISSION to rob them?
Do you GREET people when they leave?
Would most people like COUNTERFEIT money for their pay?
Do people DISCUSS things they keep secret?
Do people like to DISCARD money?
Is it fun to have an ACHE?
Is it hard to OVERCOME a powerful enemy?
Can a leaf QUIVER?
Do people need NOURISHMENT?
Would a person who tries to save people trapped in a burning building be called COURAGEOUS?
Is Washington's Birthday an ANNUAL holiday?
Do people often live in LOBBIES?
Do most churches accept CONTRIBUTIONS?
Is a SMUDGE usually beautiful?

exercise_2.tfprompt: He hated people, so he always found someone to ACCOMPANY him.
David wasn't PERMITTED to leave his room until he said he was sorry.
Susan GREETED us with a warm smile.
I could see at a glance that the stamp was a COUNTERFEIT.
No one listened to our DISCUSSION of Egyptian mummies.
Instead of DISCARDING the old furniture he fixed it up and sold it.
The flu made Jane ACHE all over.
We OVERCAME and stayed a few nights at our friend's house.
The force of the car crash made the telephone pole QUIVER.
He ran away after he broke the window because he was afraid to be NOUR- ISHED.
It was COURAGEOUS ofhim to run away when the other children were in trou-  ble.
She takes her ANNUAL vacation the first two weeks in August.
He stood in the LOBBY trying to decide which elevator to take.
Bill CONTRIBUTED his lack of success to bad luck.
By the time she finished eating, her lipstick was all SMUDGED.

definitions.deftext: to go with, be       -             with             You can see the word company in ACCOMPANY. To     ACCOMPANY someone is to be in company with him, to    go along with him.          "We will ACCOMPANY him as far as the bus stop."    "The president arrived, ACCOMPANIED by several        Secret Service men."           "High winds ACCOMPANIED the snowstorm."         ACCOMPANY is often used in the field of music.     "The singer will be ACCOMPANIED by a pianist."

to allow, authorize, make possi-      ble             To PERMIT something is to allow it, to give your consent   to it.            "Her father PERMITTED her to go to the dance."     "Smoking is not PERMITTED inside the building."       The noun from PERMIT is PERMISSION, which is the     act of allowing.           "She was given PERMISSION to speak to the class."     "The airport denied the plane PERMISSION to       land."

is also a noun, meaning      PERMISSION, especiallyPERMISSION in written form         such as a certificate or license, which allows someone to    do something.            "The school parking PERMIT was pasted on his car's     windshield."             Other forms of the word: PERMISSION, n.       PERMISSIVE, adj.            PERMISSIBLE, adj.

to welcome, meet        To GREET someone is to welcome him, to say hello to   him in a friendly way.         "We all went over to GREET the new neighbors."     "Is that any way to GREET an old friend?"     GREET can also mean to meet or receive.      "The play was GREETED with polite applause."       "They GREETED his speech with boos and hisses."      A GREETING is the act or words that you use to GREET  someone.             "He received a warm GREETING when he arrived      home."             Other forms of the word: GREETING, n.

fake, phony, not        genuine             COUNTERFEIT can be an adjective, a noun, or a verb.    As an adjective, COUNTERFEIT means fake or phony.      "They tried to spend the COUNTERFEIT money as if     it were real."           "She was caught with the COUNTERFEIT food       stamps in her possession."          A COUNTERFEIT (noun) is a copy or imitation which     someone pretends is the real thing, usually in order to    cheat a person.           "The expert said the supposedly priceless painting was      a COUNTERFEIT and actually wasn't worth any-       thing."             Finally, COUNTERFEIT is a verb meaning to fake or     pretend.             "Jane COUNTERFEITED great joy at the gift of the     pocketbook. She really thought it was ugly."       Many people choose useless as the meaning of COUN-     TERFEIT. COUNTERFEIT money may be useless, but       the basic meaning is fake, not genuine.

to talk about, talk over      To DISCUSS something is to talk about it, to exchange    opinions about it.           "We DISCUSSED where the picture should be hung."      "The teacher DISCUSSED the meanings of various       words."             "I want to DISCUSS your behavior with you."      "It's hard to DISCUSS anything with Tim. He just     gets excited and starts yelling."         The noun from DISCUSS is DISCUSSION.        "We had a long DISCUSSION about how to do the    job."             Other forms of the word: DISCUSSION, n.

to throw away, get rid of     See dis- under Prefixes. DISCARD means to throw away.     The word was first used only about throwing away cards    that weren't useful in games like poker or gin rummy.    "He picked up the queen of spades and DISCARDED     the two of clubs."          Now DISCARD is used to indicate throwing away any-     thing that isn't useful.          "Sheila DISCARDED some old, broken toys."        "I wanted to DISCARD the book, but he said it might   be valuable, so I kept it."

a dull pain        An ACHE is a dull, steady pain.       "Jane felt an ACHE in her legs after she had been run-  ning for an hour."          "Cold, wet weather always caused an ACHE in his in-    jured knee."            ACHE is also a verb, meaning "to feel a dull steady pain."  "His head ACHED from all the noise in the room."    ACHE is often used in the sense "to long for something so  much that it is almost painful."        "She ACHED to see him one last time before she left."

to defeat, surmount,        conquer             To OVERCOME something is to get the better of it. You   can OVERCOME a person, a feeling, or a thing.     "It may take years, but we will OVERCOME the ene-    my."             "He OVERCAME the urge to smoke a cigarette."      To be OVERCOME by or with something is to be weak-   ened or overpowered by it.         "She was OVERCOME with sadness when she remem-      bered what he had said."         "They were OVERCOME by the gas fumes escaping      from the car."

to shake, tremble        To QUIVER is to shake or tremble slightly. It is more of-  ten used about things than about people.       "The needle QUIVERED for a while, then stopped on     zero."             "The arrow QUIVERED in the target."        "The animal QUIVERED with fear as the men ap-     proached."             In the Pretest, many people choose freeze as the meaning    of QUIVER, probably because QUIVER looks like shiver,      and you shiver when its very cold.

food, susten-         ance             To NOURISH something is to keep it alive and strong by   feeding.             "They needed to NOURISH their plants, so they      bought some special plant food."         NOURISHMENT is that which supports life and growth;      it is food or anything else that NOURISHES.      "Even when you are sick and don't feel like eating, you   must still take some NOURISHMENT."         "Just as your body needs food, your mind needs     NOURISHMENT too."            Other forms of the word: NOURISH, v.

having COURAGE,         brave, fearless            COURAGEOUS comes from the word COURAGE, which       means bravery. See -ous under Suffixes. COURAGEOUS       means brave, fearless, having courage.         "It was very COURAGEOUS of him to stand up for    what he felt was right in the face of the others' disap-  proval."             "Her COURAGEOUS attempt to swim the English       Channel was unsuccessful."           "COURAGEOUS people do not run and hide when      things become dangerous."           Other forms of the word: COURAGE, n.

yearly          ANNUAL means "corning or happening every year."       "We will put on our seventh ANNUAL flower show     this spring."            "The party was so successful we decided to make it an   ANNUAL event."            "His ANNUAL income went up ten percent last year."

an entrance hall, waiting room      A LOBBY is a hall, room, or corridor that is used as an entrance or waiting area.          "He sat and waited in the LOBBY of the hotel until   his friends came downstairs."          The LOBBIES of places like the Senate or the House of   Representatives were where members of Congress would       meet with the public. A LOBBY has therefore also come    to mean a group of people who attempt to influence law-   makers to vote in a certain way.       "The shipping industry LOBBY spent a great deal of     money trying to get this bill passed."       A LOBBYIST is someone who attempts to influence law-     makers in this way.          Other forms of the word: LOBBYIST, n.

to give, donate        CONTRIBUTE has two related meanings. First, CON-       TRIBUTE means "to give along with others." The word     is usually used about giving money to a charity, but it can  be used about giving other things as well.      "She CONTRIBUTED several good ideas to the pro-      ject."             "If everyone CONTRIBUTES a few hours of his time     the house will be painted very quickly."       CONTRIBUTE can also mean "to help bring about."      "Extreme tiredness CONTRIBUTED to his coming        down with a very bad cold."        "A good education CONTRIBUTED to his success in      politics."             A CONTRIBUTION, the noun from CONTRIBUTE, is a      gift.             "She has made many CONTRIBUTIONS to charity in      the past year."           Other forms of the word: CONTRIBUTION, n.

a dirty mark, smear, dirt      A SMUDGE is a blurred, streaky mark, the kind that is   made when a bit of dirt is rubbed, or when something is  incompletely erased.            "There were SMUDGES on the window where the      child had put his greasy fingers."        "The paper was covered with SMUDGES after she      had finished erasing all her mistakes."        SMUDGE is also a verb.         "He SMUDGED the paper even more when he tried to    clean it up."           "She SMUDGED her cheek when she rubbed it with     her dirty hand."
